A. 0 7,13 7-13 * 1 script.go 
0 Minute
7,13 - Gets executed at 7am and 1 pm
7-13 * 1 - Only if the days are in between 7 -13 of every month and is it a Monday. Another words only if it is the send Monday of the month.

questions.question_text: An administrator wants to run a script on the second Monday of every month. The script should be executed at 7:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. Which of the following entries to the crontab will accomplish this?

discussion.content:
Ansible is a radically simple IT automation engine that automates cloud provisioning, configuration management, application deployment, intra-service orchestration, and many other IT needs.

Designed for multi-tier deployments since day one, Ansible models your IT infrastructure by describing how all of your systems inter-relate, rather than just managing one system at a time.

It uses no agents and no additional custom security infrastructure, so it's easy to deploy - and most importantly, it uses a very simple language (YAML, in the form of Ansible Playbooks) that allow you to describe your automation jobs in a way that approaches plain English

https://www.ansible.com/overview/how-ansible-works

Selected Answer: C
Besides monitoring, logging, and reporting utilities, several high-level 
orchestration engines provide agentless orchestration too. One such 
example is Red Hat’s Ansible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following configuration management tools is considered agentless?

comments.content:
I think it is json like the answer said

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
yaml all the way

This is YAML file just by looking at Syntax
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/YAMLSyntax.html
And here is JSON syntax
https://www.tutorialspoint.com/json/json_syntax.htm

This is definitely not JSON. JSON uses {} and has "" around both the keys and the values. I think it's YAML. I looked at the wikipedia page and the format is similar, though YAML looks like it has multiple valid formats

Correct Answer: A. Users can comment in YAML but not in JSON

YAML has a different feature set than JSON, including but not limited to:

1. the ability to self reference
2. support for complex datatypes
3. embedded block literals
4. comments

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a difference between YAML and JSON?

choices.A: Users can comment in YAML but not in JSON
choices.C: JSON is used in web development, while YAML is used solely in back-end systems.
choices.D: YAML has been deprecated for JSON.
choices.B: JSON only uses curly brackets, while YAML only uses square brackets

discussion.content: If space has been already allocated, that rules out "C". With "A", I don't see the purpose of deactivating a swapfile (especially, since it is not clear that the swap file even exists yet...allocating space for a swapfile isn't the same as creating a swaf file). "B" seems like the best answer since you are creating a swapfile (using a file with allocated space called "swapfile") and then enabling the swapfile using "swapon". More info here: https://linuxize.com/post/create-a-linux-swap-file/

comments.content: why do you think that? do you have a link?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A) Can't be right answer because "free : swap" is not a valid command
B) seems right answer because we need to set a new swapfile, but the change could not affect immediatelly and the ";" means to execute second command anyway of first command execution. That smells.
C) fallocate just preallocate or deallocate a space "to a file". We need to get more space, now, and we need to deallocate in this moment the swapfile. Seems perfect. Furthermore is the only choice with "&&": run second command only if first command done good job!
D) meninfo doesn't exist. Then you can't write in /proc/meMinfo. commands "swapon /" and "swapfile" are not propertly separated.

comments.content:
[SELECTED ANSWER: B]
"swapon -a" is valid only if swap area is specified in /etc/fstab.
So
 1) option1: let's consider swap area is present in /etc/fstab who knows, maybe "space has been allocated for a swap file" means a root has run commands like:
fallocate -l 1G /swapFile && chmod 0600 /swapFile && echo "/swapFile swap swap defaults 0 0" | sudo tee -a /etc/fstab

in this way root created swapFile with valid permissions and wrote in /etc/fstab necessary to use "swapon -a"

( use "free -h" to show if any changes )
-
That's means I can use:
 - "mkswap /swapFile" to convert file into swap area
 - "swapon -a" (and not "swapon /swapFile") because swap file is specified in /etc/fstab

So "B" option is valid.
in this situation "C" option is not valid because error: "fallocate failed: file busy"

 2) option2: let's consider swap area is not present in /etc/fstab
"D" option has first command wrong and useless, but second command can be always valid (if "/ swapFile" is not spaced)

That's why I think this question sucks.

discussion.content:
mkswap : - set up a Linux swap area
free: - Display amount of free and used memory in the system
fallocalte: - preallocate or deallocate space to a file
echo: -display a line of a text

Based on the above purpose of the commands, I think the right answer is B.

questions.question_text:
A junior administrator of a physical server receives log messages indicating the out-of-memory killer has been active. All memory slots are in use on the motherboard, but additional disk space is available. Space has been allocated for a swap file.
Which of the following should the administrator use to reduce the output of memory messages?
